Key Match Events: Lane Thomas hit a three-run homer, contributing significantly to the Guardians' 5-0 victory.
Six Cleveland relievers combined for seven innings of four-hit ball after Ben Lively departed with a leg injury.
Chicago White Sox were shut out for the 17th time this season, finishing with five hits.
White Sox rookie Jonathan Cannon was charged with three runs and seven hits in 5 1/3 innings.
Sean Burke made his major league debut, pitching three innings and allowing one run and three hits.
Post-Match Reflections: Lane Thomas reflected on his recent performance, stating, 'You just work day in and day out, and eventually you find something that kind of helps.'
Manager Stephen Vogt praised his relievers, saying, 'Those guys stepped up in a huge way. They were all efficient. Did their job, and then some.'

Interim manager Grady Sizemore commented on the White Sox's performance, 'We had a couple of good swings here and there. We got some guys on, but just not the big hit when guys were on and weren’t able to grind at-bats and make them work at all.'
Ben Lively shared his thoughts on his injury, 'It hit me and like my leg just gave out. Next thing I know I was on the ground and it was just stinging.'

Sean Burke expressed his excitement about his debut, 'It was unbelievable. This is definitely the best day of my life. It’s something I’ve worked for since I picked up a baseball for the first time. It’s hard to put into words right now.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: At 33-113, the White Sox are closing in on the post-1900 record for losses — 120 by the 1962 New York Mets in their inaugural season.
Cleveland's bullpen has a 37-11 record and a major league-best 2.76 ERA.
Guardians left-hander Matthew Boyd (2-1, 2.20 ERA) and White Sox right-hander Davis Martin (0-3, 3.29 ERA) are set to pitch in the series finale.
Others: Guardians: RHP Alex Cobb (blister on his right middle finger) is throwing weighted balls, and LHP Joey Cantillo is in line to start on Saturday.
LHP Sam Hentges is going to have shoulder surgery on Sept. 18 and is expected to be sidelined for about a year.
White Sox: RHP Drew Thorpe said his season-ending elbow surgery went as expected and should have a normal offseason.
INF Brooks Baldwin (right wrist sprain) is still experiencing pain when hitting.
